title: Modeling Actuations in BCI-O: A Context-based Integration of SOSA and IoT-O

sentences.text: Recent technological developments in Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) will largely enable BCI as a powerful, natural and intuitive mainstream human-computer interaction (HCI) in real-world activities, especially throughout actuators connected to the Internet.
As a type of sensor-actuator system, BCI will integrate novel interfaces that will be fully interoperating with IoT-based systems.

An ontological metadata overlay for BCI systems in real-world applications is defined in the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which formalizes and integrates BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with a novel Context Model for describing any kind of real/virtual environments.
This paper presents the design principle of BCI-O's Actuation Model, which integrates SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms for actuations and actuators along with the BCI-O's Context Model.

This model will become relevant in the degree as context-based semantic interoperability will become a core pre-requisite for any context-aware BCI actuation application with real-time collaboration in IoT environments.

Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) are systems that determine a user's brain states by collecting and analyzing her neurophysiological signals (which are highly situational, individual dependent, and non-stationary in characteristics) and then actuating specific responses, for example to drive her wheelchair autonomously.

Key developments in wearable sensors, wireless networks, and distributed computing will largely enable BCI as a powerful, natural and intuitive mainstream human-computer interaction (HCI) in real-world activities.
In a not too far future, BCI will be regarded as the ultimate HCI system, integrating novel interfaces that will be fully interoperating with Internet-of-Things- (IoT)-based systems.
In this scenario, context-based semantic interoperability will be a core pre-requisite for any context-aware BCI application with real-time collaboration in IoT environments.

The BCI Ontology (BCI-O) [1] is the first OWL 2 ontology that formalizes relevant metadata for BCI data capture activities by integrating BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with a novel Context Model for describing any kind of real/virtual environments.

Due that BCI is a type of sensor-actuator system, as an ontological metadata overlay for BCI systems in real-world applications, BCI-O is properly aligned with the W3C Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) and Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA) [2] upper ontologies.

Because many BCI devices, especially actuators, are connected to the Internet, BCI-O is also aligned with the core actuation semantic model for the IoT ontology (IoT-O) [3]: the Semantic Actuator Network (SAN) [5].
BCI-O makes an important contribution: the introduction of the concepts of context and contextual relations [1].

This puts the architectural description of any context as a first-class semantic model that enables BCI applications to be context-aware, laying the foundations of meaningful interactions with IoT-based systems.
This paper presents the structure and design principle of BCI-O's Actuation Model, which integrates SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms for actuations and actuators along with the BCI-O's Context Model.
A use case for this model is explained in a subsequent section.
Lastly, the main contribution is summarized in the conclusions.
BCI-O origins, purpose, core models, global overview, public access (spec and examples), design principles, and applications are described in [1].

At its core, BCI-O defines the conceptual components in any BCI through a bidirectional subject-context interaction model (a BCI session with sensors/actuators): a Sense Model (context to subject) and an Actuation Model (subject to context), as depicted in Fig. 1.
Its Actuation Model is based on the
Two distinct conceptual domains are found in this interaction model: BCI domain (observations, actuations, and interactions) and context domain (surroundings).
Following, a brief description of BCI-O's core modules related to actuations are presented:
Session: represents the interaction between a bci:Subject and a bci:Context while performing (bci:Session) a single bci:Activity.
A bci:Session groups both observations (multimodal records: bci:Record) and actuations (bci:Actuation).
Context: captures the architectural description of any physical/virtual environment.
Its conceptual components enable the structural, functional, and temporal complexity definitions of any environment (Fig. 4).

Under the bci:Context.Event classification, BCI-O defines three key concepts that bind the contextual integration (including with its Actuation Model): bci:StimulusEvent (a stimulus to the bci:Subject), bci:Action (issued by a bci:Subject while performing a bci:Activity), and bci:ActuationEvent (an effect -change of state- in bci:Context as the result of bci:Actuation).
Observations: describes the contextual input data and events to the subject [3].
Specific concepts aligned to the SOSA/SSN axioms [2] are defined for modeling observations.

These are related to bci:Record (a single observation, and input to an actuator), bci:Modality types, aspects (bci:Aspect), channeling specs (bci:ChannelingSpec), sensor output (bci:RecordedData), and bci:StimulusEvent.
Actuation: integrated concepts aligned to the SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms for modeling actuations and actuators.
This model depicts how the bci:Subject can interact with the bci:Context [3].
This model was developed based on the following premises:
Aims to integrate and reconcile SOSA and SAN axioms for modeling actuations and actuators (Fig. 2 and Fig. 3).
Follows closely the proposed Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) ontology design pattern [4]: a core model for the IoT Ontology (IoT-O)1 [3] (Fig. 3).
3.1 Core Abstractions
Actuation: Carries out a procedure to change the state of the context using an actuator.
The relationships from and to actuation and other concepts are the ones defined at [2].
bci:Actuation is aligned to both sosa:Actuation and san:Actuation.

Actuation Event: Represents a transition (something that has changed from a state to a different one: actuation target) ─ a modification (impacted property, as a consequence of an actuation effect) ─ in the context as the result of an actuation (actuation result involves actuation event).
From the context perspective, this concept is a context event (triggered by an actuator) that changes the impacted property of the actuation target.
bci:ActuationEvent is aligned to both bci:Context.Event and san:Effect.
Following the AAE ODP [4], this concept is taken from the following relationships involving the san:Effect definition [5]:
san:Actuator - (triggers) -> san:Effect
san:Actuation - (involves) -> san:Effect
san:Effect - (impacts) -> bci:ImpactedProperty
Actuation Result: It represents the result of an actuation [2], i.e. an entity representing the “effect” of the actuation, which involves an actuation event.
bci:ActuationResult is aligned to both sosa:Result and san:ActuationValue.
Following the AAE ODP [4], this concept expands the following relationship:
san:Actuation - (involves) -> san:Effect
Actuation Target: Its modeling depiction is based on the composition of three concepts.
The first, as a sosa:FeatureOfInterest [2]: the thing (actuation target) whose property (impacted property) is being manipulated by an actuator.

The second, related from a sosa:Actuation via the property sosa:hasFeatureOfInterest [2]: a relation between an actuation and the entity (actuation target) whose property (an impacted property as a consequence of an actuation effect) was modified.
And the third one, a bci:Context.Object: a thing (object) in the contextual interaction of the bci:Session.
bci:ActuationTarget is aligned to both bci:Context.Object and sosa:FeatureOfInterest.
Following the AAE ODP [4], this concept captures the definition of sosa:FeatureOfInterest from the following relation:
bci:ImpactedProperty - (is property of) -> sosa:FeatureOfInterest
Actuator: A device that is used by, or implements, an actuation that changes the state of the context.
According to [3], actuators are devices that transform an input signal into a physical output, making them the exact opposite of sensors.
bci:Actuator is aligned to both sosa:Actuator and san:Actuator.
Command: Represents a specific order (based on a bci:Record) to an actuator to perform an actuation.
Typically, it depicts an instruction (or signal) that causes an actuator to perform (executes) one of its basic functions, and thus, triggering an actuation.
A command defines the input for a set of actuators from a specific source: a set of bci:Record.
bci:Command is aligned to both dul:Method and san:ActuatorInput.
Following the AAE ODP [4], this concept is based on the following definition:
[AAE::Actuator] - (AAE::consumes) -> [AAE::Input]
bci:Actuator - (bci:executes) -> bci:Command
Impacted Property: Represents an actuatable quality (property or characteristic) of an actuation target.

An actuator connects to an impacted property (as a consequence of an actuation effect) via the object property ssn:forProperty [2], i.e., an actuator triggers an actuation event that causes an effect (modification) on the actuation target: impacted property [4].
bci:ImpactedProperty is aligned to sosa:ActuatableProperty.
Following the AAE ODP [4], this concept captures the definition of Impacted Property (linked to san:Effect) from the following relationships:
san:Effect - (impacts) -> bci:ImpactedProperty
bci:ImpactedProperty - (is property of) -> sosa:FeatureOfInterest
3.2 Modeling Integration: BCI-O Context Model with SOSA and SAN Alignments
As a broad application domain ontology for BCI activities, BCI-O integrates and refines some modeling considerations of the SOSA and SAN concepts regarding actuations and actuators.
The “context-aware” domain level concepts were aligned initially to SOSA/SSN.
Afterwards, they were integrated with proper alignments to SAN (IoT-O), following closely their axiomatization satisfiability.
The main modeling integration was done with the actuation event alignment to san:Effect (or san:ActuatorOutput).
san:Effect is defined in [5] as “concept bound to the definition of an actuator as an agent having an effect on the physical world.
Therefore, an effect is any kind of physical modification induced by an actuator”.

In order to be more semantically precise, and based on the SOSA/SSN definitions aligned with Dolce-Ultralite (DUL) in [2] (Vertical Segmentation: DUL alignment module), the concept san:Effect is described distinctively by the following combined ontological notions along with BCI-O's Context Model:

A happening that impacts a quality (dul:Quality), or property (ssn:Property), with the capability of an actuation to act on it (sosa:actsOnProperty), that is, a type of sosa:ActuatableProperty, i.e. the bci:ImpactedProperty.
An event (dul:Event) triggered by an actuator, that modifies (changes) the physical world (actuation target): a type of bci:Context.Event; the actuation event.

(An effect is seeing as...) Any kind (of an impacted property) of physical modification (an effect on the physical world — context) as the result of an actuation (an actuation result involves an actuation event), induced by an actuator (a characteristic of its nature, as an agent that has an effect on the context).
An actuation event is a bci:Context.Event triggered by an actuator that changes the state of the actuation target (which is a bci:Context.Object) (see Fig. 4).
Another inherited modeling perspective for BCI, comes from the definition of san:impacts object property: san:Effect - ( san:impacts ) -> oldssn:Property.
Also, BCI-O's alignment to SAN allows the following inferred relationship:
bci:ActuationEvent - (·san:impacts·) -> bci:ImpactedProperty

Last, in order to be consistent in the BCI-O's overall structure and intention, direct alignments to DUL were considered carefully evaluating the scope and constraints for each concept, which led to properly define class hierarchies and disjoint axioms, especially for its Actuation Model.
The following use case depicts how to define related BCI-O actuation concepts (its description and source code is available online in the spec's human-readable version [1]).
Its purpose is to use an actuator capable to control a wheelchair based on the input from a BCI/EEG record (obtained directly from the subject's head).

In this use case, Alice is driving a wheelchair throughout a human interface composed of three major components: (1) an EEG sensor capable of reading brain signals, (2) a computing system capable to process and analyze (classify) the brain signals collected from the EEG sensor, and (3) an actuator capable to control the wheelchair's movement (such as direction and acceleration) based on the input from the EEG recordings.

The actuator is a device that implements the procedure (actuation) to control the wheelchair, which triggers a series of steps aimed to change the wheelchair's state, such as to decelerate its wheels.
The input to the actuator are the observed and processed brain signals that issue specific movement commands.
For example, the “slow down” command with the parameters (and values) of “direction” (“go forward” -no change in the direction-) and “acceleration” (-10.5 cm/s² -change in the speed-).
The modeled concepts involved in this scenario (see Fig.5), excluding those from the observation component (except EEG-Record and EEG-Device), are listed below:
bci:Subject (1 individual = x1): “Alice”.
bci:Session (x1): “a situation where the EEG recording and actuation happened”.
bci:Activity (x1): “controlling the automated wheelchair”.
bci:Context (x1): “at home”.
bci:Context.Scene (x1): “specific indoors situation”.
bci:EegRecord (x1): “EEG observation that serves as the input of the actuations”.
bci:EegDevice (x1): “EEG device that made the EEG recordings”.
bci:Command (x1): “slow down”, actuators' input from the EEG record.
bci:Actuator (2 individuals = x2): “the devices that perform the actuations”.
bci:Actuation (x2): “procedures that change the state of the wheels via actuators”.
bci:ImpactedProperty (x2): “the speed of the wheels (their state)”.
bci:ActuationEvent (x2): “reduce the speed of wheels”.
bci:ActuationResult (x2): “slowing down” (“effect of decelerating the wheels”).
bci:ActuationTarget (x2): “two rear wheels”.
bci:Context.Object (composite) (x1): “wheelchair”.
bci:Context.Method (x1): “deceleration of a wheel”.

BCI-O's Actuation Model provides a mechanism to correlate the observed/analyzed raw data [1], with the contextual components that the subject interacts with, through actuators (IoT devices), identifying how the actuations affect the context.
This is useful in BCI context-aware applications to model how subjects use actuators and interact with the environment, for “intelligent” subject-context personalization.
BCI-O's Actuation Model integrates carefully both standard axiomatization models for actuations, developed by W3C/OGC [2] and IoT [3] [5] communities, based on its Context Model.
Thus, its structure follows closely the AAE ODP [4], while aligning to SOSA/SSN and SAN (IoT-O) concepts, based on contextual notions.

The SOSA-SAN integrated Actuation Model of BCI-O represents a major contribution to the IoT and BCI communities, especially because its structure includes contextual notions that enables its usage in context-aware BCI-IoT integrated applications.
Semantically-enabled BCIs will play a key role in the future “Internet of Brains” interoperating completely with IoT [6].

Under this vision, where one could semantically model, interoperate and control real life objects throughout BCIs connected to the Internet, BCI-O's Actuation Model would become a core semantic structure that integrates BCI, IoT, and contextual concepts in real-world scenarios.

It is important noting that as part of the BCI-O's Actuation Model development, the author raised the issue to the W3C Spatial Data on the Web Working Group [7], regarding the mapping of SOSA/SSN to AAE ODP, due of their structural resemblance.

summary:
Recent technological developments in Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) will largely enable BCI as a powerful, natural and intuitive mainstream human-computer interaction (HCI) in real-world activities, especially throughout actuators connected to the Internet. As a type of sensor-actuator system, BCI will integrate novel interfaces that will be fully interoperating with IoT-based systems. An ontological metadata overlay for BCI systems in real-world applications is defined in the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which formalizes and integrates BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with a novel Context Model for describing any kind of real/virtual environments. This paper presents the design principle of BCI-O's Actuation Model, which integrates SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms for actuations and actuators along with the BCI-O's Context Model. This model will become relevant in the degree as context-based semantic interoperability will become a core pre-requisite for any context-aware BCI actuation application with real-time collaboration in IoT environments.

Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) are systems that determine a user's brain states by collecting and analyzing her neurophysiological signals (which are highly situational, individual dependent, and non-stationary in characteristics) and then actuating specific responses, for example to drive her wheelchair autonomously. Key developments in wearable sensors, wireless networks, and distributed computing will largely enable BCI as a powerful, natural and intuitive mainstream human-computer interaction (HCI) in real-world activities. In a not too far future, BCI will be regarded as the ultimate HCI system, integrating novel interfaces that will be fully interoperating with Internet-of-Things- (IoT)-based systems. In this scenario, context-based semantic interoperability will be a core pre-requisite for any context-aware BCI application with real-time collaboration in IoT environments. The BCI Ontology (BCI-O) [1] is the first OWL 2 ontology that formalizes relevant metadata for BCI data capture activities by integrating BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with a novel Context Model for describing any kind of real/virtual environments. Due that BCI is a type of sensor-actuator system, as an ontological metadata overlay for BCI systems in real-world applications, BCI-O is properly aligned with the W3C Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) and Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA) [2] upper ontologies. Because many BCI devices, especially actuators, are connected to the Internet, BCI-O is also aligned with the core actuation semantic model for the IoT ontology (IoT-O) [3]: the Semantic Actuator Network (SAN) [5]. BCI-O makes an important contribution: the introduction of the concepts of context and contextual relations [1]. This puts the architectural description of any context as a first-class semantic model that enables BCI applications to be context-aware, laying the foundations of meaningful interactions with IoT-based systems. This paper presents the structure and design principle of BCI-O's Actuation Model, which integrates SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms for actuations and actuators along with the BCI-O's Context Model. A use case for this model is explained in a subsequent section. Lastly, the main contribution is summarized in the conclusions.

BCI-O origins, purpose, core models, global overview, public access (spec and examples), design principles, and applications are described in [1]. At its core, BCI-O defines the conceptual components in any BCI through a bidirectional subject-context interaction model (a BCI session with sensors/actuators): a Sense Model (context to subject) and an Actuation Model (subject to context), as depicted in Fig. 1. Its Actuation Model is based on the

Two distinct conceptual domains are found in this interaction model: BCI domain (observations, actuations, and interactions) and context domain (surroundings). Following, a brief description of BCI-O's core modules related to actuations are presented:

Session: represents the interaction between a bci:Subject and a bci:Context while performing (bci:Session) a single bci:Activity. A bci:Session groups both observations (multimodal records: bci:Record) and actuations (bci:Actuation).

Context: captures the architectural description of any physical/virtual environment. Its conceptual components enable the structural, functional, and temporal complexity definitions of any environment (Fig. 4). Under the bci:Context.Event classification, BCI-O defines three key concepts that bind the contextual integration (including with its Actuation Model): bci:StimulusEvent (a stimulus to the bci:Subject), bci:Action (issued by a bci:Subject while performing a bci:Activity), and bci:ActuationEvent (an effect -change of state- in bci:Context as the result of bci:Actuation).

Observations: describes the contextual input data and events to the subject [3]. Specific concepts aligned to the SOSA/SSN axioms [2] are defined for modeling observations. These are related to bci:Record (a single observation, and input to an actuator), bci:Modality types, aspects (bci:Aspect), channeling specs (bci:ChannelingSpec), sensor output (bci:RecordedData), and bci:StimulusEvent.

Actuation: integrated concepts aligned to the SOSA and SAN (IoT-O) axioms for modeling actuations and actuators. This model depicts how the bci:Subject can interact with the bci:Context [3].

The BCI-O (Brain-Computer Interface Ontology) integrates SOSA and SAN axioms to model actuations and actuators. It follows the Actuation-Actuator-Effect ontology design pattern, aligning with IoT-ontology. The main concepts include: Actuation, which carries out a procedure using an actuator; Actuation Event, representing a transition in context as a result of an actuation; Actuation Result, representing the effect of an actuation; and Impacted Property, representing an actuatable quality of an actuation target.

The following use case depicts how to define related BCI-O actuation concepts (its description and source code is available online in the spec's human-readable version [1]). Its purpose is to use an actuator capable to control a wheelchair based on the input from a BCI/EEG record (obtained directly from the subject's head). In this use case, Alice is driving a wheelchair throughout a human interface composed of three major components: (1) an EEG sensor capable of reading brain signals, (2) a computing system capable to process and analyze (classify) the brain signals collected from the EEG sensor, and (3) an actuator capable to control the wheelchair's movement (such as direction and acceleration) based on the input from the EEG recordings. The actuator is a device that implements the procedure (actuation) to control the wheelchair, which triggers a series of steps aimed to change the wheelchair's state, such as to decelerate its wheels. The input to the actuator are the observed and processed brain signals that issue specific movement commands. For example, the “slow down” command with the parameters (and values) of “direction” (“go forward” -no change in the direction-) and “acceleration” (-10.5 cm/s² -change in the speed-). The modeled concepts involved in this scenario (see Fig.5), excluding those from the observation component (except EEG-Record and EEG-Device), are listed below:

bci:Subject (1 individual = x1): “Alice”. bci:Session (x1): “a situation where the EEG recording and actuation happened”. bci:Activity (x1): “controlling the automated wheelchair”. bci:Context (x1): “at home”. bci:Context.Scene (x1): “specific indoors situation”. bci:EegRecord (x1): “EEG observation that serves as the input of the actuations”. bci:EegDevice (x1): “EEG device that made the EEG recordings”. bci:Command (x1): “slow down”, actuators' input from the EEG record. bci:Actuator (2 individuals = x2): “the devices that perform the actuations”. bci:Actuation (x2): “procedures that change the state of the wheels via actuators”. bci:ImpactedProperty (x2): “the speed of the wheels (their state)”. bci:ActuationEvent (x2): “reduce the speed of wheels”. bci:ActuationResult (x2): “slowing down” (“effect of decelerating the wheels”). bci:ActuationTarget (x2): “two rear wheels”. bci:Context.Object (composite) (x1): “wheelchair”. bci:Context.Method (x1): “deceleration of a wheel”.

BCI-O's Actuation Model provides a mechanism to correlate the observed/analyzed raw data [1], with the contextual components that the subject interacts with, through actuators (IoT devices), identifying how the actuations affect the context. This is useful in BCI context-aware applications to model how subjects use actuators and interact with the environment, for “intelligent” subject-context personalization.

BCI-O's Actuation Model integrates carefully both standard axiomatization models for actuations, developed by W3C/OGC [2] and IoT [3] [5] communities, based on its Context Model. Thus, its structure follows closely the AAE ODP [4], while aligning to SOSA/SSN and SAN (IoT-O) concepts, based on contextual notions. The SOSA-SAN integrated Actuation Model of BCI-O represents a major contribution to the IoT and BCI communities, especially because its structure includes contextual notions that enables its usage in context-aware BCI-IoT integrated applications. Semantically-enabled BCIs will play a key role in the future “Internet of Brains” interoperating completely with IoT [6]. Under this vision, where one could semantically model, interoperate and control real life objects throughout BCIs connected to the Internet, BCI-O's Actuation Model would become a core semantic structure that integrates BCI, IoT, and contextual concepts in real-world scenarios. It is important noting that as part of the BCI-O's Actuation Model development, the author raised the issue to the W3C Spatial Data on the Web Working Group [7], regarding the mapping of SOSA/SSN to AAE ODP, due of their structural resemblance.

Predicate-will_enable.label: will enable
Predicate-will_enable.description: The predicate 'will enable' indicates that the subject has the potential to create or facilitate an opportunity for something (the object) to happen, become possible, or be achieved. It suggests a causal relationship between the subject and the object, implying that the subject's existence, development, or application will lead to the emergence of the described possibility.

Predicate-as.label: as
Predicate-as.description: The predicate 'as' indicates a classification or identification of the subject with respect to the object. It suggests that the subject shares characteristics, properties, or qualities similar to those described by the object.

Predicate-throughout.label: throughout
Predicate-throughout.description: The predicate 'throughout' indicates a spatial or temporal scope within which something occurs. It suggests that an action, process, or state extends over the entire duration of its existence, encompassing all parts or moments simultaneously.

Predicate-integrate.label: integrate
Predicate-integrate.description: To combine or unify different elements into a cohesive whole, often resulting in a new entity that exhibits emergent properties. This process typically involves bringing together distinct components to form a harmonious and functional system.

Predicate-defines.label: defines
Predicate-defines.description: The predicate 'defines' indicates a relationship where the subject provides a clear and explicit explanation or description of the object, establishing its meaning, scope, or boundaries. This connection implies that the subject has authority over the definition of the object, which can be an ontology, concept, term, or any other abstract entity.

Predicate-determine.label: determine
Predicate-determine.description: To determine means to establish or identify a connection between two entities (subject and object), typically involving measurement, analysis, or interpretation. The subject, often an entity capable of processing information, uses its capabilities to extract relevant features from the object, resulting in a clear understanding or definition of the object's characteristics.

Predicate-will_largely_enable.label: will largely enable
Predicate-will_largely_enable.description: The predicate 'will largely enable' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject's actions or existence will have a significant impact on the object's capabilities, functionality, or potential. In general, it implies that the subject's influence will be substantial enough to bring about a notable change in the object.

Predicate-be_regarded_as.label: be regarded as
Predicate-be_regarded_as.description: The predicate 'be regarded as' indicates a subjective evaluation or assessment of the subject by others. It implies that the object represents an interpretation, classification, or characterization of the subject in some way.

Predicate-fully_interoperating_with.label: fully interoperating with
Predicate-fully_interoperating_with.description: The predicate 'fully interoperating with' indicates a state of seamless communication and coordination between two entities (subject and object), where each entity can exchange information, share resources, or perform tasks together without any hindrances or barriers. This relationship implies that both parties are able to understand and respond to each other's actions, messages, or requests in a harmonious manner.

Predicate-will_be_a_core_pre-requisite_f.label: will be a core pre-requisite for
Predicate-will_be_a_core_pre-requisite_f.description: Indicates that the subject has a fundamental requirement or condition necessary to achieve or exist alongside the object. The predicate highlights an essential prerequisite for the object's development, functionality, or success.

Predicate-require.label: require
Predicate-require.description: The predicate 'require' indicates that a subject has an inherent or necessary need for something specified by the object. It implies a sense of necessity, obligation, or expectation between the subject and the object.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' indicates a relationship of equivalence or identity between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has the same nature, quality, or characteristics as the object.

Predicate-integrates.label: integrates
Predicate-integrates.description: The predicate 'integrates' indicates a relationship where the subject (a conceptual framework or system) brings together disparate components, concepts, or models to form a unified whole. This integration can be seen as a process of combining and harmonizing distinct elements into a coherent structure that facilitates understanding, analysis, or application.

Predicate-includes.label: includes
Predicate-includes.description: The predicate 'includes' indicates that the subject (a concept or entity) contains or encompasses the object as a part of its definition, scope, or structure. In general, it suggests a relationship where the subject has some level of containment, membership, or relevance to the object.

Predicate-is_properly_aligned_with.label: is properly aligned with
Predicate-is_properly_aligned_with.description: The predicate 'is properly aligned with' indicates a relationship where two or more conceptual frameworks, ontologies, or standards share commonalities and are mutually consistent. This alignment suggests that the subject's concepts, entities, or principles have been mapped to or corresponded with those of the object, enabling interoperability, integration, or harmonization between them.

Predicate-are_connected_to.label: are connected to
Predicate-are_connected_to.description: The predicate 'are connected to' indicates a relationship of association or linking between two entities. It suggests that there exists some kind of logical or physical bond, pathway, or channel that enables communication, interaction, or exchange between the subject and object.

Predicate-makes_an_important_contributio.label: makes an important contribution to
Predicate-makes_an_important_contributio.description: The predicate 'makes an important contribution to' indicates a relationship between the subject (BCI-O in this case) and the object, where the subject has played a significant role in advancing or developing the concept, idea, or field represented by the object. This connection suggests that the subject's actions, research, or efforts have had a meaningful impact on the evolution of the object, making it more comprehensive, accurate, or influential.

Predicate-enables.label: enables
Predicate-enables.description: The predicate 'enables' indicates that the subject has a facilitating or empowering effect on the object. It suggests that the subject provides the necessary conditions, resources, or support for the object to function, operate, or achieve its intended purpose.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates that the subject provides or offers the object to consideration, attention, or understanding. It implies a sense of introduction, exposition, or revelation, where the subject serves as a medium for conveying information about the object.

Predicate-is_explained_in_a_subsequent_s.label: is explained in a subsequent section for
Predicate-is_explained_in_a_subsequent_s.description: This predicate indicates that the subject provides context or background information necessary to understand the object. The object represents a concept, idea, or principle that requires further explanation for its meaning and significance to be grasped. In this sense, the predicate serves as a bridge between the subject's relevance and the object's importance.

Predicate-is_summarized_as.label: is summarized as
Predicate-is_summarized_as.description: The predicate 'is summarized as' indicates that a subject (typically an abstract concept or idea) can be condensed into a concise form, which is represented by its object. This connection implies that the subject's essence or main points are captured and presented in a simplified manner through the object.

Predicate-are.label: are
Predicate-are.description: The predicate 'are' indicates a relationship of equivalence or similarity between the subject and object. It suggests that both entities share common characteristics, properties, or attributes, implying a sense of unity or coherence.

Predicate-describes.label: describes
Predicate-describes.description: The predicate 'describes' connects a subject (typically an entity or concept) to its representation or characterization through language. It indicates that the object, which may be a text, description, or summary, provides information about the subject's nature, properties, or characteristics.

Predicate-depicts.label: depicts
Predicate-depicts.description: The predicate 'depicts' indicates a representation or illustration relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject conveys its meaning through the visual or conceptual content of the object.

Predicate-uses.label: uses
Predicate-uses.description: The predicate 'uses' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g., BCI-O) employs or utilizes an object (e.g., Sense Model), often implying a functional connection between them. This connection can be characterized by the subject leveraging, exploiting, or making use of the object's properties, capabilities, or context to achieve some purpose or goal.

Predicate-is_based_on_the.label: is based on the
Predicate-is_based_on_the.description: The predicate 'is based on the' indicates a relationship where the subject relies on or has its foundation in the object. It suggests that the subject's existence, validity, or meaning is grounded in or derived from the information provided by the object.

Predicate-are_found_to_have.label: are found to have
Predicate-are_found_to_have.description: The predicate 'are found to have' indicates a discovery or identification of a relationship between two entities (subject and object), suggesting that the subject possesses, contains, or exhibits the characteristics or properties described by the object.

Predicate-has.label: has
Predicate-has.description: The predicate 'has' indicates a possession or association relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject possesses, includes, or is composed of the object, which can be an attribute, characteristic, module, or other entity.

Predicate-interacts_with.label: interacts with
Predicate-interacts_with.description: The predicate 'interacts with' indicates a relationship where the subject (an entity or agent) engages with and affects the object (another entity, context, or environment), potentially influencing its state, behavior, or properties.

Predicate-performs.label: performs
Predicate-performs.description: The predicate 'performs' indicates that the subject entity executes or carries out an activity, task, or function described by the object. It represents a relationship of execution, implementation, or accomplishment between the two entities.

Predicate-contains.label: contains
Predicate-contains.description: The predicate 'contains' indicates a relationship where the subject has or includes the object as part of its composition. This can be understood broadly to mean that the subject encompasses, holds, or possesses the object within itself.

Predicate-enable.label: enable
Predicate-enable.description: To enable means to make something possible or feasible by providing the necessary conditions, resources, or understanding. It implies a facilitative relationship between the subject and object, where the subject provides the foundation for the object's existence, functionality, or comprehensibility.

Predicate-is_a_stimulus_to_the.label: is a stimulus to the
Predicate-is_a_stimulus_to_the.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has an effect or influence on the object. The relationship between the subject and object is one of causality, where the subject serves as a trigger or motivator for some action or reaction from the object.

Predicate-binds_the_contextual_integrati.label: binds the contextual integration including with its Actuation Model
Predicate-binds_the_contextual_integrati.description: Establishes a connection between a stimulus event and an actuation process by integrating context into the processing of the actuation model.

Predicate-defined_for.label: defined for
Predicate-defined_for.description: The predicate 'defined for' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, concepts) has its meaning or scope determined by the object (modeling observations). In general, it suggests that the subject's definition or characterization is contingent upon or grounded in the context provided by the object.

Predicate-aligned_to.label: aligned to
Predicate-aligned_to.description: The predicate 'aligned to' indicates a relationship between two entities where one entity (the subject) has its meaning or structure intentionally matched with, conformed to, or based on another entity (the object). This alignment can be seen as an intentional mapping of the subject's concepts onto those defined by the object. The resulting connection enables the subject to leverage the semantic context and constraints provided by the object.

Predicate-related_to.label: related to
Predicate-related_to.description: The predicate 'related to' indicates a connection or association between two entities. It suggests that there exists some kind of relationship, similarity, or correspondence between the subject and object.

Predicate-can_interact_with.label: can interact with
Predicate-can_interact_with.description: The predicate 'can interact with' indicates a relationship where the subject (an entity or system) has the capability to engage, communicate, or exchange information with another entity or system represented by the object. This interaction can take various forms, such as data transfer, command execution, or sensory perception.

Predicate-based_on_the.label: based on the
Predicate-based_on_the.description: The predicate 'based on the' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g., Actuation Model) relies on or draws inspiration from the object (e.g., Two distinct conceptual domains), suggesting that the subject's characteristics, principles, or foundations are rooted in or derived from the object.

Predicate-was_developed_based_on.label: was developed based on
Predicate-was_developed_based_on.description: The predicate 'was developed based on' indicates a relationship between an idea or concept (the subject) and its underlying foundation or inspiration (the object). It suggests that the development of something was guided by, informed by, or built upon certain principles, theories, or premises. In general, this predicate highlights the intellectual or conceptual origins of a particular creation, model, or theory.

Predicate-modeling.label: modeling
Predicate-modeling.description: The predicate 'modeling' represents a process of creating or representing an abstract representation of real-world phenomena, systems, or processes. It indicates that the subject aims to create a conceptual framework or simulation that captures essential characteristics and relationships between entities, such as actuations and actuators.

Predicate-are_integrated_and_reconciled_.label: are integrated and reconciled by
Predicate-are_integrated_and_reconciled_.description: This predicate indicates a process of combining or merging two entities (the subject) into a unified whole that resolves any conflicts or inconsistencies between them. The resulting entity is connected to and governed by the object, which provides the framework for their integration.

Predicate-Carries_out_a_procedure_to_cha.label: Carries out a procedure to change the state of the context using an actuator
Predicate-Carries_out_a_procedure_to_cha.description: This predicate describes the action of implementing a specific process or protocol that alters the current situation or environment by utilizing a device capable of producing a desired effect. The subject (actuations in this example) performs an operation to modify its context using an actuator, which serves as a tool for achieving the intended outcome.

Predicate-are_defined_at.label: are defined at
Predicate-are_defined_at.description: This predicate indicates that a set of concepts or entities (subject) have their meanings, boundaries, or scope established by reference to some external point or framework (object). The object can be any type of entity that serves as a anchor for understanding the subject's definition.

Predicate-involves.label: involves
Predicate-involves.description: The predicate 'involves' indicates a relationship of participation or inclusion between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has some level of involvement, connection, or association with the object, which can be physical, logical, causal, or other types of relationships.

Predicate-represents_a_transition_from_a.label: represents a transition from a state to a different one
Predicate-represents_a_transition_from_a.description: This predicate indicates that the subject (an actuation event or similar phenomenon) marks a change of status from an initial state to another, distinct one. The object represents the target or outcome of this transition.

Predicate-impacts.label: impacts
Predicate-impacts.description: The predicate 'impacts' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject has an effect or influence on the object. The impact can be positive, negative, direct, indirect, or even subtle, but it implies some kind of change or consequence for the object.

Predicate-has_impacted_property.label: has impacted property
Predicate-has_impacted_property.description: The predicate 'has impacted property' indicates a relationship where the subject (an entity or concept) has had an effect on or influenced the object (a property), resulting in some change, modification, or alteration to that property.

Predicate-aligned_with.label: aligned with
Predicate-aligned_with.description: Indicates a relationship of correspondence or congruence between two entities, where one entity (the subject) has its characteristics, properties, or behavior matched with those of another entity (the object).

Predicate-taken_from.label: taken from
Predicate-taken_from.description: The predicate 'taken from' indicates a relationship where the subject (Following) originates or derives its meaning, context, or significance from the object (actuation event). This connection suggests that the subject's identity, purpose, or relevance are tied to the occurrence of the actuation event.

Predicate-triggers.label: (triggers)
Predicate-triggers.description: The predicate '(triggers)' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the occurrence or action described by the subject has led to, caused, or brought about the state or effect represented by the object.

Predicate-is_aligned_to.label: is aligned to
Predicate-is_aligned_to.description: Indicates a relationship of correspondence or equivalence between two entities. The subject and object are connected by this predicate when they share similar characteristics, properties, or meanings.

Predicate-follows.label: follows
Predicate-follows.description: The predicate 'follows' indicates that there exists a causal relationship between the subject and object, where the subject's state or condition leads to or results in the described modification or transition represented by the object.

Predicate-is_a.label: is a
Predicate-is_a.description: The predicate 'is a' establishes an instance-of relationship between the subject and object. It indicates that the subject is a specific example or manifestation of the concept, class, or category represented by the object.

Predicate-hasFeatureOfInterest.label: hasFeatureOfInterest
Predicate-hasFeatureOfInterest.description: Indicates that a subject has an interest-bearing feature or characteristic described by the object. This predicate establishes a connection between the subject and the object, highlighting the significance of the object's role with respect to the subject.

Predicate-modified_by.label: modified by
Predicate-modified_by.description: The 'modified by' predicate indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the subject's characteristics or properties are influenced or determined by the object. The object serves as a modifier, shaping or defining the nature of the subject.

Predicate-be_in_the_contextual_interacti.label: be in the contextual interaction of
Predicate-be_in_the_contextual_interacti.description: The predicate 'be in the contextual interaction of' indicates a relationship where the subject (a context object) participates or engages with another entity (the session), which can be understood as an interactive process, dialogue, conversation, or exchange that takes place within a specific context. This connection suggests that the context plays a crucial role in facilitating this interaction.

Predicate-is_property_of.label: is property of
Predicate-is_property_of.description: The predicate 'is property of' establishes a relationship between two entities where one entity (the subject) has some inherent or characteristic quality, attribute, or feature that belongs to another entity (the object). This connection indicates that the subject's properties are derived from or closely related to those of the object.

Predicate-be_opposite_of.label: be opposite of
Predicate-be_opposite_of.description: The predicate 'be opposite of' indicates a relationship between two entities where one entity (the subject) has an opposing or contrasting function, role, or purpose compared to another entity (the object).

Predicate-represents_a_specific_order_ba.label: represents a specific order based on
Predicate-represents_a_specific_order_ba.description: This predicate indicates that the subject (a command or instruction) has its meaning or significance derived from a specific ordering principle or structure defined by the object, which can be a record, list, sequence, or other ordered collection. The connection between the subject and object is one of semantic dependence, where the meaning of the subject relies on the underlying order specified in the object.

Predicate-executes.label: executes
Predicate-executes.description: The predicate 'executes' indicates the act of carrying out or putting into effect a plan, instruction, or decision. It represents the subject's action of taking control and implementing the object, which can be an order, command, policy, or other type of directive.

Predicate-perform.label: perform
Predicate-perform.description: To perform indicates a subject's execution or carrying out of an action, task, function, or role. The predicate connects the subject to the object by describing what the subject does or accomplishes.

Predicate-Represents.label: Represents
Predicate-Represents.description: The predicate 'Represents' indicates a conceptual connection between its subject and object. It suggests that the subject embodies, symbolizes, or stands for the qualities or characteristics described by the object. In this sense, it establishes an abstract relationship between the two entities, highlighting their shared meaning or significance.

Predicate-represents_an_actuatable_quali.label: represents an actuatable quality (property or characteristic) of
Predicate-represents_an_actuatable_quali.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has a property or characteristic that can be acted upon or influenced by an external factor. The object represents the aspect of the subject's nature that can be modified, controlled, or manipulated.

Predicate-connects_to.label: connects to
Predicate-connects_to.description: The predicate 'connects to' indicates a relationship where the subject (an entity or component) has an influence or control over the object (another entity, property, or aspect), often implying a direct or indirect causal link between them.

Predicate-causes_an_effect_modification_.label: causes an effect (modification) on the actuation target
Predicate-causes_an_effect_modification_.description: This predicate indicates a causal relationship between the subject (an actuation event) and the object (the actuation target), where the subject's occurrence leads to an effect or modification on the object. The predicate highlights the dynamic interaction between the two entities, emphasizing that the subject has brought about a change in the state of the object.

Predicate-captures_the_definition_of.label: captures the definition of
Predicate-captures_the_definition_of.description: This predicate indicates that the subject (an actuation event or similar phenomenon) has a direct influence on the object (a concept or property), effectively defining its meaning, scope, or characteristics.

Predicate-linked_to.label: linked to
Predicate-linked_to.description: The predicate 'linked to' indicates a relationship where the subject and object are connected or associated with each other. This connection can be based on various factors such as causality, similarity, analogy, or shared characteristics.

Predicate-regarding.label: regarding
Predicate-regarding.description: The predicate 'regarding' indicates a relationship of relevance or pertinence between the subject (SOSA) and object (actuations and actuators), suggesting that SOSA has some connection, consideration, or focus on actuations and actuators.

Predicate-done_with.label: done with
Predicate-done_with.description: Indicates that a process or activity has been completed and terminated its relationship with an object. The subject represents the entity that performed the action of being done with, while the object refers to the thing or concept that was involved in this termination.

Predicate-is_described_distinctively_by.label: is described distinctively by
Predicate-is_described_distinctively_by.description: This predicate indicates a distinctive description or characterization of one concept (subject) by another concept (object), suggesting that the object provides a unique and defining perspective on the subject.

Predicate-is_impacted_by.label: is impacted by
Predicate-is_impacted_by.description: The predicate 'is impacted by' indicates a relationship where the subject (a property or characteristic) has its value, behavior, or significance influenced or affected by the object (an actuatable quality of an actuation target). This connection suggests that the presence and/or characteristics of the object have some degree of influence on the nature, scope, or interpretation of the subject.

Predicate-triggered_by.label: triggered by
Predicate-triggered_by.description: The predicate 'triggered by' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, where the subject's occurrence or existence leads to or causes the object. It suggests that the object plays a role in initiating or setting off the process or event described by the subject.

Predicate-changes.label: changes
Predicate-changes.description: The predicate 'changes' indicates a transformation or alteration from one state to another between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject (in this case, an event) has brought about or caused a change in the state of something else (the actuation target), resulting in a new or modified condition.

Predicate-comes_from.label: comes from
Predicate-comes_from.description: Indicates a causal or originative relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject has its source, foundation, or inspiration in the object.

Predicate-aligns_to.label: aligns to
Predicate-aligns_to.description: The predicate 'aligns to' indicates a correspondence or similarity between two entities (subject and object), suggesting that they share common characteristics, patterns, or structures. This connection implies a level of coherence, consistency, or equivalence between the subject and object.

Predicate-evaluating_the_scope_and_const.label: evaluating the scope and constraints for each concept, which led to properly define class hierarchies and disjoint axioms
Predicate-evaluating_the_scope_and_const.description: This predicate describes the process of analyzing and understanding the boundaries and limitations (scope and constraints) for each concept or idea. This analysis leads to a clear definition of relationships between concepts, as represented by class hierarchies, and ensures that these relationships do not overlap or contradict one another through disjoint axioms.

Predicate-depicts_how_to_define_related.label: depicts how to define related
Predicate-depicts_how_to_define_related.description: This predicate indicates that the subject provides a representation or illustration of the process by which two or more entities are connected or associated. The object represents the concept, framework, or methodology used to establish these relationships.

Predicate-define_related_BCI-O_actuation.label: define related BCI-O actuation concepts
Predicate-define_related_BCI-O_actuation.description: This predicate connects a subject (e.g., BCI-O) to an object (e.g., use case), indicating that related concepts of actuation are being defined or described. The predicate highlights the relationship between the subject and the object, emphasizing the context-specific nature of these definitions.

Predicate-use.label: use
Predicate-use.description: The predicate 'use' indicates a relationship where the subject has a purpose or intention to employ, utilize, or make use of something (the object), often in order to achieve a specific goal or outcome.

Predicate-based_on_the_input_from.label: based on the input from
Predicate-based_on_the_input_from.description: The predicate 'based on the input from' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject's behavior or functioning is determined by the information or data provided by the object. In other words, the subject relies on the input from the object to operate or make decisions.

Predicate-control_a_wheelchair_based_on_.label: control a wheelchair based on input from a BCI/EEG record
Predicate-control_a_wheelchair_based_on_.description: The predicate 'control a wheelchair based on input from a BCI/EEG record' describes an action where the subject (e.g. Actuator) regulates or manages the movement of the object (e.g. wheelchair), making decisions and taking control based on neural signals recorded by Brain-Computer Interface (BCI)/Electroencephalography (EEG).

Predicate-driving.label: driving
Predicate-driving.description: The predicate 'driving' indicates the subject's control and operation of a vehicle or device, often with the intention to move it from one place to another. The object represents the medium through which this action takes place.

Predicate-reading.label: reading
Predicate-reading.description: The predicate 'reading' indicates that the subject is acquiring or interpreting information from the object. It implies a process of extracting meaning or understanding from the data, signal, or text provided by the object.

Predicate-processing.label: processing
Predicate-processing.description: The predicate 'processing' indicates that the subject is performing some kind of analysis or manipulation on the object. This can involve transforming, analyzing, interpreting, or generating information from the object, often with a goal of extracting meaningful insights, making decisions, or taking actions.

Predicate-drives.label: drives
Predicate-drives.description: The predicate 'drives' indicates a relationship where the subject (a person or entity) operates and controls the object (typically a vehicle), often in a deliberate and intentional manner.

Predicate-are_read_by.label: are read by
Predicate-are_read_by.description: The predicate 'are read by' indicates a relationship where the subject (information or data) is interpreted, understood, or deciphered through the agency of the object. The object serves as an intermediary that facilitates the processing and comprehension of the subject's meaning.

Predicate-processes_and_analyzes_classif.label: processes and analyzes (classifies) the brain signals collected from
Predicate-processes_and_analyzes_classif.description: This predicate describes an action of processing, analyzing (and potentially classifying), and extracting meaningful information from a collection of brain signals obtained from a specific source. The subject performing this action takes the collected brain signals as input and produces insights or patterns that can be used for further analysis or decision-making.

Predicate-reads.label: reads
Predicate-reads.description: The predicate 'reads' indicates that the subject acquires or interprets information from the object. It implies a process of extracting meaning or understanding from the object, which can be a physical medium (e.g., text), an abstract concept (e.g., data), or even a person's thoughts or emotions.

Predicate-implements.label: implements
Predicate-implements.description: The predicate 'implements' indicates that the subject (an entity or system) carries out or enacts a specific procedure, process, or method described by the object. In general, it represents the relationship between an agent and its corresponding action or protocol.

Predicate-triggers_a_series_of_steps_aim.label: triggers a series of steps aimed to change the state of
Predicate-triggers_a_series_of_steps_aim.description: This predicate indicates that the subject initiates or causes a sequence of actions or processes designed to modify or alter the object's current status, condition, or configuration.

Predicate-receive.label: receive
Predicate-receive.description: To receive indicates a process of obtaining or getting something, often in an intentional manner. It implies that the subject takes possession of or becomes aware of the object's information, signal, or content.

Predicate-issue.label: issue
Predicate-issue.description: To issue means to produce or generate something, typically a response, command, or instruction. In this sense, it connects the subject (the input) with the object (observed and processed brain signals that issue specific movement commands), indicating that the input is responsible for producing or generating these brain signals.

Predicate-are_used_by.label: are used by
Predicate-are_used_by.description: The predicate 'are used by' indicates a relationship of utilization or application, where the subject (in this case, observed and processed brain signals that issue specific movement commands) provides input or control to the object (an actuator capable to control the wheelchair's movement), which then executes or implements some action based on that input.

Predicate-involved_in.label: involved in
Predicate-involved_in.description: The predicate 'involved in' indicates a relationship between the subject (a set of concepts) and an object (an event, process, or scenario), suggesting that the subject has some level of participation, contribution, or connection to the object. This can imply various degrees of involvement, such as being part of, participating in, influencing, or affected by the object.

Predicate-excluding_those_from.label: excluding those from
Predicate-excluding_those_from.description: The predicate 'excluding those from' indicates a relationship where the subject excludes or omits certain entities (those referred to by the object), which are typically characterized as being part of, belonging to, or originating from something. This predicate suggests that the subject is not considering or including these specific entities in its scope, whereas it may still consider other entities within the same category.

Predicate-happened.label: happened
Predicate-happened.description: The predicate 'happened' indicates that an event or occurrence took place at a specific point in time. It connects the subject (Session 1) to the object (EEG recording and actuation), suggesting that these events co-occurred, were concurrent, or had some causal relationship.

Predicate-via.label: via
Predicate-via.description: The predicate 'via' indicates a means or method by which an action or process occurs. It connects the subject (the procedures that change the state of the wheels) to the object (Actuator), suggesting that the actuators are the instruments or tools used to achieve this outcome.

Predicate-provides.label: provides
Predicate-provides.description: The predicate 'provides' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, BCI-O) offers or makes available something to someone or something else. In general, it suggests that the subject has access to or possesses the object (Actuation Model), and is willing or able to share it with others.

Predicate-correlate_with.label: correlate with
Predicate-correlate_with.description: To correlate with means to establish a relationship or connection between two entities (subject and object), typically involving patterns, trends, or associations that exist between them. This predicate implies an investigation into the co-occurrence of events, variables, or phenomena, aiming to identify potential links, dependencies, or causal relationships.

Predicate-use_actuators_and_interact_wit.label: use actuators and interact with
Predicate-use_actuators_and_interact_wit.description: To 'use actuators and interact with' means to employ mechanical or electronic devices (actuators) to engage with a system, entity, or context (object), typically resulting in some form of feedback, response, or manipulation. This predicate implies an intentional action by the subject to influence or affect the object through controlled movements or interactions.

Predicate-developed_by.label: developed by
Predicate-developed_by.description: The predicate 'developed by' indicates that the subject entity was responsible for creating, designing, or bringing into existence the object concept. It implies a causal relationship between the subject and the object, suggesting that the subject played a key role in shaping or producing the object.

Predicate-follows_closely.label: follows closely
Predicate-follows_closely.description: The predicate 'follows closely' indicates a close relationship or similarity between the subject and object. It suggests that there is a strong connection, correspondence, or affinity between them.

Predicate-aligning_to.label: aligning to
Predicate-aligning_to.description: The predicate 'aligning to' indicates a relationship where the subject's structure or organization is being matched, correlated, or mapped to the object's conceptual framework. This connection implies that there is an attempt to harmonize or reconcile the subject with the object's concepts, standards, or principles.

Predicate-represents_a_major_contributio.label: represents a major contribution to the
Predicate-represents_a_major_contributio.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has made a significant and influential impact on or advancement within the scope of the object. The connection between the subject and object suggests that the subject's work, concept, idea, etc., has had a profound effect on the field, community, or area denoted by the object.

Predicate-follows_closely_the_structure_.label: follows closely the structure of
Predicate-follows_closely_the_structure_.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has a similar organizational or structural pattern to the object. It suggests a close correspondence between the internal structure of the two entities, implying a high degree of similarity and possibly even equivalence.

Predicate-will_become.label: will become
Predicate-will_become.description: The predicate 'will become' indicates a transformation or evolution from one state to another. It implies that the subject (the degree as context-based semantic interoperability in this case) will undergo a change, resulting in it taking on new characteristics or properties described by the object (BCI systems in real-world applications). The connection between the subject and object is one of anticipation or expectation, suggesting that the transformation will lead to a future state where the two entities are more closely related.

Predicate-aligns.label: aligns
Predicate-aligns.description: The predicate 'aligns' indicates a relationship where the subject and object are brought into correspondence or congruence. It suggests that there exists a harmonious connection, similarity, or coherence between the two entities, allowing them to share common characteristics, principles, or goals.

Predicate-is_described_in.label: is described in
Predicate-is_described_in.description: The predicate 'is described in' indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the subject's characteristics, properties, or features are explained or detailed within the context of the object. The object provides a framework for understanding or describing the subject.

Predicate-model.label: model
Predicate-model.description: To represent or simulate a conceptual framework that explains and predicts phenomena, behaviors, or patterns. The predicate 'model' establishes an abstract representation of a system, process, or phenomenon, which can be used to understand, analyze, predict, or control its behavior.

Predicate-align.label: align
Predicate-align.description: To align means to bring into a state of correspondence or congruence between two entities, concepts, or frameworks. It implies establishing a connection, matching, or synchronizing elements, properties, or principles between them.

Predicate-is_described_by.label: is described by
Predicate-is_described_by.description: Indicates that a subject (e.g., an entity, concept, or object) has its characteristics, properties, or essence captured by the description provided in the object. This predicate establishes a connection between the subject and the descriptive content, suggesting that the latter accurately represents or conveys information about the former.

Predicate-requires.label: requires
Predicate-requires.description: The predicate 'requires' indicates a necessary condition or prerequisite for something to exist, happen, or be achieved. It implies that the subject has an inherent need or dependence on the object to fulfill its purpose, function, or goal.

Predicate-will_integrate.label: will integrate
Predicate-will_integrate.description: To predicate 'will integrate' means to indicate that two entities (subject and object) are expected to combine or unify their respective functions, capabilities, or aspects into a cohesive whole. This integration implies a harmonious relationship between the subject's core competencies and the object's inherent properties, resulting in enhanced performance, efficiency, or value.

Predicate-formalize.label: formalize
Predicate-formalize.description: To formalize means to give a systematic and standardized structure or framework to something, such as an idea, concept, or process. This predicate connects the subject (the thing being formalized) with the object (the resulting structured entity), indicating that the subject is transformed into a more organized, coherent, and perhaps abstract representation.

Predicate-define.label: define
Predicate-define.description: To establish a clear and precise meaning or explanation for something. The predicate 'define' connects the subject to an object by providing a concise description, classification, or interpretation of what the subject represents.

Predicate-describe.label: describe
Predicate-describe.description: To describe means to convey a representation or characterization of something about an entity (subject), providing insight into its properties, behaviors, or relationships with other entities. The predicate 'describe' establishes a connection between the subject and object by capturing essential features, patterns, or structures that define the subject's nature.

Predicate-will_become_relevant_in.label: will become relevant in
Predicate-will_become_relevant_in.description: The predicate 'will become relevant in' indicates a temporal and contextual connection between the subject (a concept or idea) and the object (another concept, principle, model, etc.). It suggests that the subject will gain significance, importance, or applicability within the scope of the object's context. In other words, it implies that the subject's relevance is conditional upon being situated within the framework defined by the object.

Predicate-based_on.label: based on
Predicate-based_on.description: The predicate 'based on' indicates a relationship where the subject (design principle) relies on or derives its foundation from the object (Actuation Model of BCI-O). It suggests that the subject's characteristics, principles, or concepts are grounded in or rooted within the object. In general, this predicate connects the subject to an underlying framework, theory, methodology, or authority that provides a basis for understanding or justifying the subject.

Predicate-enable_integration.label: enable integration
Predicate-enable_integration.description: To enable integration means to facilitate or make possible the connection and interaction between different entities, systems, or components. This predicate indicates that something (the subject) provides a mechanism or framework for combining disparate parts into a cohesive whole, allowing them to work together seamlessly.

Predicate-integrate_seamlessly.label: integrate seamlessly
Predicate-integrate_seamlessly.description: To connect or unify two entities (e.g., systems, technologies, concepts) without any gaps, inconsistencies, or disruptions, resulting in a harmonious and efficient whole.

Predicate-requires_(1).label: requires
Predicate-requires_(1).description: The predicate 'requires' indicates that a certain condition or property must be met for something to exist, operate, or function properly. It implies a necessary relationship between the subject and object, where the subject needs or depends on the object to fulfill its purpose.

Predicate-become.label: become
Predicate-become.description: The predicate 'become' indicates the transformation or evolution of a subject into a new state, quality, or condition. It implies a change from one situation to another, where the object represents the desired outcome or result that the subject will attain.

Predicate-is_relevant_for.label: is relevant for
Predicate-is_relevant_for.description: The predicate 'is relevant for' indicates that the subject has a bearing or significance on the object, implying that the subject's characteristics, properties, or implications are important or influential in understanding or achieving the object. In general, this predicate suggests a connection between the subject and object where the former provides insight, guidance, or context necessary to comprehend or utilize the latter.

Predicate-present.label: present
Predicate-present.description: The predicate 'present' indicates that the subject and object are currently existing or available. It suggests a state of being where both entities coexist, with no distinction between past, present, or future.

Predicate-aligns_with.label: aligns with
Predicate-aligns_with.description: The predicate 'aligns with' indicates a connection between two concepts or frameworks that share common principles, goals, or underlying structures. It suggests a harmonious relationship where one concept (the subject) has similarities and correspondences with another concept (the object), often implying mutual understanding, coherence, or compatibility.

Predicate-formalizes.label: formalizes
Predicate-formalizes.description: Formalizes establishes a precise and systematic representation of concepts or structures, typically through a standardized framework or set of rules. This predicate indicates that the subject has created a formalized version of the object, which may involve abstraction, categorization, or codification.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: Indicates that the subject concept is a more specific instance of the object concept in a hierarchical classification or categorization system.
